A no brainer….Trump!

There are many issues in this election, but one central issue hasalways been what most significantly divides the Republicans fromthe Democrats. Republicans favor Free Enterprise Capitalism andseek to empower investors and industry to expand, grow, andemploy while limiting government spending. Democrats lean towardSocialism and seek to tax investors and industry for the purposesof distributing wealth to the masses via large social spending programs.Throughout history, societies that favor Free Enterprise Capitalism andgrow their economies via private sector incentives are societies that growand prosper. Societies that over-tax investors and private sector industrytend to stagnate and decline. Even China, which is an authoritarian, one-party state, greatly accelerated it's wealth and prosperity over the last 25years though capitalist reforms and incentives.In this election, the choice between a Free-enterprise capitalist candidateand a big government socialist candidate has never been more stark.Mr. Trump governed as the former and expanded GDP faster, 8 to 10 yearsfollowing the most recent recession, at all time record rates and he did itwith minimal inflation and very high employment.Biden/Harris passed record social spending and gunned inflation to the highestlevels in over 40 years, which led to high interest rates and everything from eggsto housing extremely unaffordable and wages/salaries significantly lagging thecost of living.The choice, should be very clear.

As shareholders, speculating about what robotaxi can and can’t do for comfort with our investment is folly.  What we are seeing is a transformative shift in technology from Tesla that will eventually destroy our company absent proactive and competent management. First thing is to lower cost overall and sell or close down Lime scooters as it adds nothing to the company. Next is to repair the relationship with drivers and delivery people. Happy people being the face to interact with customers goes a long way when technology is a threat to labor. Customers love to interact with happy people and get frustrated when technology doesn’t perform as expected which plays to an advantage if done correctly.

There is time to do this right and no need to panic unless we see that Dara doesn’t recognize the need to change the company and can’t make the transition. Another option is to sell the company as quickly as possible.

The technology is being invented as we speak in many companies. In fact multiple articles I have seen mention that FSD for TSLA is a hardware issue as much as a software issue. They think they can solve their hardware issue with a software. Think of a human without eyes. They would need a stick with a rolling ball at the end to navigate to a degree of normalcy. But without eyes it would never truly be a normal process to navigate. Hence sensors are important which TSLA neglects beyond a camera via its vision. Other companies understand the importance of sensors and of course optimizing software that is complemented by hardware…etc. Musks arrogance will eventually affect his business model and so will the competition. There will be other av companies pushing better products, there will be better AI companies pushing better products, and of right now companies like BYD are pushing equivalent if not better ev cars at a lower cost compared to TSLA. Soon to follow more companies in the ev space that will implement better tech. Being politically polarized and being in business only goes so far before the candle burns on both ends. Here is a rundown of policy differences. This is not an endorsement.Mr. Trump recently stated that he supports reducing the top corporate income tax bracketfrom 21% to 15% in order to help companies like UBER to compete strongly against foreigncompetitors. 7 years ago, Mr. Trump spearheaded reducing the rate from 35% to 21%.Ms. Harris proposes increasing the top corporate rate from 21% to 28%, a 25% increase inincome tax UBER would have to pay instead of investing in it's growth.Mr. Trump wants to maintain the current long-term capital gains tax on sales of UBER stockat 15% and 20% for higher earners.Ms. Harris proposes taxing capital gains taxes as ordinary earnings. So an investor in the 28% marginal income tax bracket would see in increase in capital gains taxes on UBER stock sales from 15% to 28%, almost doubling the tax owed. Ms. Harris also proposes, with Mr. Biden,to impose the tax on "unrealized" gains, on UBER stock that an investor owns but has not yetsold. The unrealized gain tax would be imposed on higher earners.Mr. Trump lowered personal income tax brackets across the board in 2017. Those reductions will "sunset" (end) in 2025 if they are not renewed. Mr. Trump wants to renew them. Ms. Harris avoids the subject, but Mr. Biden has expressed disdain for the 2017 reductions. The increased standard deduction would also sunset. If the brackets sunset and increase to the pre-2017 levels, so too would the cap-gains tax with Harris's proposal.
